item.title: Killing a Process that is using a specific Port
item.description: 2023-10-13 Learned about the -t flag on lsof. It will just return the port #’s I’ve been using lsof for years, but as a two-step process. Now I can do it all in one go. I went ahead and added a snippet for this in Raycast sudo kill -kill $(sudo lsof -t -i :5432)
item.content:encoded:
• 2023-10-13
    • Learned about the -t flag on lsof. It will just return the port #’s
    • I’ve been using lsof for years, but as a two-step process. Now I can do it all in one go.
    • I went ahead and added a snippet for this in Raycast sudo kill -kill $(sudo lsof -t -i :5432)

item.title: Move forward with decisions that are easily adjusted later
item.description: Significant time is lost over-discussing choices that can be easily adjusted later. If it can be changed painlessly later, choose what appears to be a decent option and revisit this in a retrospective where you’ll have more information.
item.content:encoded: Significant time is lost over-discussing choices that can be easily adjusted later. If it can be changed painlessly later, choose what appears to be a decent option and revisit this in a retrospective where you’ll have more information.

item.title: The Case For Boredom
item.description: Do you ever find that often solve a key problem, or have a novel idea when in the shower, just to find that you have no ability to jot those ideas down? I call those Shower Thoughts. Have you ever wondered why you get these epiphanies in the shower? Well, there are a number of scientific reasons why, but let’s focus on just one of them today, Boredom. When you’re in the shower, you don’t have your TV, computer, phone. (If I’m being honest, I sometimes I have my phone, but I don’t recommend that). Because you don’t have these things you’re forced to be one with your thoughts, and from a dopamine perspective they can be pretty boring in comparison to those devices, but Boredom breeds creativity.
item.content:encoded:
Do you ever find that often solve a key problem, or have a novel idea when in the shower, just to find that you have no ability to jot those ideas down? I call those Shower Thoughts. Have you ever wondered why you get these epiphanies in the shower? Well, there are a number of scientific reasons why, but let’s focus on just one of them today, Boredom. When you’re in the shower, you don’t have your TV, computer, phone. (If I’m being honest, I sometimes I have my phone, but I don’t recommend that). Because you don’t have these things you’re forced to be one with your thoughts, and from a dopamine perspective they can be pretty boring in comparison to those devices, but Boredom breeds creativity. That boredom and being alone with your thoughts is what leads to these great ideas.

My 2003 Dodge Dakota doesn’t connect to my phone and has a pretty terrible sound system. Hell, it doesn’t even have cabin air filters (Although I wish it did), but I often find that I get these Shower Thoughts here as well (because I’m left alone with my thoughts). So, I will leave you with a simple call-to-action: Shower Thoughts don’t have to be reserved for just the shower, you can have them anywhere, you just need to have the courage to put down your phone, and not fight the boredom.

item.title: aged tasks
item.description: I love this quote from Khe Hy: >One of the quiet stressors of modern task management is your aged tasks. The digital nature of our lives makes it easy to add something to the list – yet never act upon it. So here’s an easy antidote: • Go into your task list and sort by incomplete, oldest first • Look at the dates, yes there’s going to be some old stuff in there • Create a rule (i.e. “If it’s been there for more than 3 months, delete”) For me, there’s something that feels inherently bad about mass-deleting tasks (at least without looking at them), so I propose a slightly different approach at curing the symptom of task overwhelm.
item.content:encoded:
I love this quote from Khe Hy: >One of the quiet stressors of modern task management is your aged tasks. The digital nature of our lives makes it easy to add something to the list – yet never act upon it. So here’s an easy antidote: • Go into your task list and sort by incomplete, oldest first • Look at the dates, yes there’s going to be some old stuff in there • Create a rule (i.e. “If it’s been there for more than 3 months, delete”)

For me, there’s something that feels inherently bad about mass-deleting tasks (at least without looking at them), so I propose a slightly different approach at curing the symptom of task overwhelm. Instead, we should move these tasks to some form of a Someday Backlog and then revisit that with an appropriate frequency. Perhaps once a quarter or twice a year. It will feel good to see how many of those tasks you actually took care or are no longer relevant.

Task Management

item.title: Braggadocio and the Modern Web
item.description: This is not a particularly new idea, but I was feeling it this morning, so I decided to write about it. In the modern internet, social media and collective culture, arrogance is rewarded with more attention, and in this case more clicks. There is little space for “this is how I do things” in hopes of someone sharing alternative approaches that perhaps you didn’t know about or had not stuck for you. Instead, “The Ultimate Guide to X” is rewarded, even if it’s not the Ultimate Guide at all. I suppose bravado and arrogance has always been rewarded in sales, but I still wonder why that’s the case.
item.content:encoded:
This is not a particularly new idea, but I was feeling it this morning, so I decided to write about it. In the modern internet, social media and collective culture, arrogance is rewarded with more attention, and in this case more clicks. There is little space for “this is how I do things” in hopes of someone sharing alternative approaches that perhaps you didn’t know about or had not stuck for you. Instead, “The Ultimate Guide to X” is rewarded, even if it’s not the Ultimate Guide at all.

I suppose bravado and arrogance has always been rewarded in sales, but I still wonder why that’s the case. I suppose bravado wins on the outset and then quality and consistency wins over time?

Meta

Braggadocio Bravado Arrogance Confidence

item.title: Hold 45 Minutes A Day to Write
item.description: You don’t have to write, but you can’t do anything else. A key challenge I have with this if I prefer to write on the computer, and it’s filled with too many other distractions. The reMarkable could theoretically solve this with the reMarkable 2 Type Folio, but I find typing on it distracting. Writing Writing as a habit
item.content:encoded:
You don’t have to write, but you can’t do anything else.

A key challenge I have with this if I prefer to write on the computer, and it’s filled with too many other distractions. The reMarkable could theoretically solve this with the reMarkable 2 Type Folio, but I find typing on it distracting.

Writing Writing as a habit

item.title: 7 habits of highly successful YouTubers
item.description: Author: Colin and Samir URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VQ89d0ilocU Have an Athlete’s Mentality Hold 45 Minutes A Day to Write Ideally, any video you create would still be helpful in 10 years time. If not, should you be producing that video? YouTube
item.content:encoded:
• Author: Colin and Samir
  • URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VQ89d0ilocU

Have an Athlete’s Mentality Hold 45 Minutes A Day to Write Ideally, any video you create would still be helpful in 10 years time. If not, should you be producing that video?

YouTube

item.title: how to make a killer youtube intro (for the 2023 algorithm)
item.description: Author: Aprilynne Alter URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TOHQXdCAo5k&t=4s YouTube Intro should be between 10 and 45 seconds Reiterate the Title in the first 5 seconds to minimize drop off Ideally the image from the intro matches that of the thumbnail (perhaps don’t start with my headshot?) The most successful videos exceed the title and thumbnail’s expectations Create Curiosity Gaps to keep people watching Provide Context so that everyone can participate even if they’re not an expert (I may have butchered this one) Leverage Input Bias by communicating how much effort and time you put into the video so that the viewer will value the video.
item.content:encoded:
• Author: Aprilynne Alter
  • URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TOHQXdCAo5k&t=4s

YouTube Intro should be between 10 and 45 seconds

Reiterate the Title in the first 5 seconds to minimize drop off

  • Ideally the image from the intro matches that of the thumbnail (perhaps don’t start with my headshot?)

The most successful videos exceed the title and thumbnail’s expectations

Create Curiosity Gaps to keep people watching

Provide Context so that everyone can participate even if they’re not an expert (I may have butchered this one)

Leverage Input Bias by communicating how much effort and time you put into the video so that the viewer will value the video.

Show people, don’t tell them. Give an intro that creates interest even if there isn’t audio. Frontload Stimulus. Many successful YouTubers change their intro visuals more than once every 2 seconds.

YouTube YouTube Formula

item.title: VIM QuickFix Lists
item.description: :copen to open :ccl to clear :colder to grab the previous one :cnewer to grab the newer one :cdo run a command for each entry in the QuickFix ex: :cdo s/findstring/replacestring | update :cfdo runs once for each file in the quickfix list :vimgrep /yoursearch/ app/** To search a directory and put it in a Quick Fix List VIM Neovim Source: Andrew Courter https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AuXZA-xCv04
item.content:encoded:
:copen to open :ccl to clear :colder to grab the previous one :cnewer to grab the newer one :cdo run a command for each entry in the QuickFix

  • ex: :cdo s/findstring/replacestring | update :cfdo runs once for each file in the quickfix list

:vimgrep /yoursearch/ app/** To search a directory and put it in a Quick Fix List

VIM Neovim

Source:

Andrew Courter https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AuXZA-xCv04

item.title: Neovim
item.description: Switching to VIM might be one of the hardest things I’ve ever done Settings up Neovim checklist Use a simple distro, like LazyNvim Set up comfort of home shortcuts Use VIM Motions in your current editor for a week or two Get Tmux set up Close Buffer (CMD+W) Learn about IW and AW motions Learn about I and A Learn about Visual Mode Reopen last tab (CMD+SHIFT+T) Learn about Leap Set up Grep Live Args Learn about F and T Learn about / and * Install Vim Visual Multi Learn about Buffers and Windows and how they are different to tabs and tab panes Learn about QuickLists Learn about Telescope Learn about Registers and Marks Install Harpoon Use nvim not nvim * Learn about nvim-surround
item.content:encoded:
Switching to VIM might be one of the hardest things I’ve ever done

Settings up Neovim checklist

  • Use a simple distro, like LazyNvim
  • Set up comfort of home shortcuts
    • Use VIM Motions in your current editor for a week or two
    • Get Tmux set up
    • Close Buffer (CMD+W)
    • Learn about IW and AW motions
    • Learn about I and A
    • Learn about Visual Mode
    • Reopen last tab (CMD+SHIFT+T)
    • Learn about Leap
    • Set up Grep Live Args
    • Learn about F and T
    • Learn about / and *
    • Install Vim Visual Multi
    • Learn about Buffers and Windows and how they are different to tabs and tab panes
    • Learn about QuickLists
    • Learn about Telescope
    • Learn about Registers and Marks
    • Install Harpoon
    • Use nvim not nvim *
    • Learn about nvim-surround

item.title: How to search for files on the terminal
item.description: Install fzf find . -type f | fzf --preview 'less {}' You can also do this with ripgrep rg --files -g '!*.spec*' -g '!*.scss' | rg modal
item.content:encoded:
Install fzf

find . -type f | fzf --preview 'less {}'

You can also do this with ripgrep rg --files -g '!*.spec*' -g '!*.scss' | rg modal

item.title: Practical Success Metrics
item.description: It’s a bit like Functional Strength in exercise. Instead of focusing on being able to lift a ton of weight, focus on being able to do the crucial things in your life.
item.content:encoded: It’s a bit like Functional Strength in exercise. Instead of focusing on being able to lift a ton of weight, focus on being able to do the crucial things in your life.
